reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS Review: Boss Monster

Tired of playing the good guy? I feel you, my friend. If you are looking for some place to fight some heroes, luring them into your deadly traps or cast some mighty (and again, deadly) spells, Boss Monster might be the right choice. But be aware, the other Monsters aren’t your allies so don’t expect them to help you.

Simply put: Boss Monster is the adaptation of the indie-card game of the same name where different bosses try to be the most evil villain trough hero slaying so If you expected a game like Dungeon Master, you should stop reading right now.

Let’s get started quickly. At first, choose between single - or multiplayer. You can play worldwide, invite friends, play hot seat or simply fight against the AI. Picking your boss monster comes next. We have Mummy Cleopatra, Xyzax the Lich, Seducia the Siren and many more, each with a unique Special Ability that can be activated only once every game. So what is the Main Goal of every match? To win, you have to be the first boss that collected 10 Hero Souls and to do so you have to slay, of course, heroes. But be aware, heroes making it through your sidescrolling dungeon will hit you with 1 wound, epic heroes even 2 wounds. To make sure that you don’t take the maximum of 5 wounds and die, playing your cards wisely is inevitable. Build rooms, use synergies, activate abilities and cast spells if necessary. Heroes need to be attracted, that’s why every room has at least one Treasure Icon. If you see that there is a mage in town and you want to lure him, build more rooms with a spellcasting icon. Same goes for fighters, clerics and thieves. The game comes with a tutorial, right before the first match or always available in the settings, making me stop the basic overview now.

Boss Monster delivers old-school 8-Bit Graphics and a NES-like Soundtrack that tends to get annoying after a while. The virtual cards look great and have funny descriptions, the same goes for heroes and our beloved villains. But some issues affected my gameplay and are already discussed in the forum. Just to mention some: The game has been released for iPad as well and thus suffers from a bad resolution in terms of Text-Boxes and general User Interface. The overall gameplay seems to be slow since you can interfere with every move heroes or opposing bosses perform. To do so you always have to check different buttons instead of just playing cards like spells that can be instantly performed, meaning Clicks, Clicks, Clicks…
Playing with more than 1 opponent means you have to click on the other icons to check the rooms they built, since there are only 2 bosses displayed at once. Playing solo is fun indeed but the lack of story condemns Boss Monster to be a game best enjoyed in Multi-Player. Thus I tried to enter a worldwide match, waiting for 45 mins until I cancelled the queue. Let’s sum it up.

Big Text, Quick Facts:

Pro:
Great idea since Boss Monster is the adaptation of an indie-tabletop game
Retro Graphics and Sound fit into the setting
Various Bosses, Rooms, Spells and Heroes to choose from or interact with
Single and Multi-Player available, Hot Seat is fun and works with “Turn your head, mate”
Short but satisfying Games - expect 15-25 Mins for KI-Matches
Card-Gallery sums up every available card so far
Con:
Interface needs an adjustment for PC
Solo-Game lacks a bit of replayability since there is no story-content
Worldwide Multiplayer is dead (Okay, Early Access and Launch 8th May 2015)
KI could be harder
6,99 seems to be too much for a game that looks like a mobile port (Appstore, Buttons are well placed for big thumbs)

Summary:
My inner demons are still fighting while writing this so I should make it clear. I recommend this game, yes. For its idea, its “easy to learn, hard to master” gameplay and the overall retro-look, sound and artwork.
This game is still in Early Access and needs not only lots of improvements regarding UI and getting rid of all these unnecessary clicks it took over from the mobile port but also more content for solo-players. Devs are working on Bugs, crashes people were talking about didn’t occur for me while playing about 10 games, so progress is happening. Gather your friends and invite them to online matches and increase the worldwide player-base or take your girl/boyfriend and hate each other in a Hot Seat match.

If you are not sure about it, don’t buy it now, wait for a sale instead. 6,99 Seems to be more of a future investment than a price that reflects its current state.

6/10

I will update this review to make sure that further progress is happening and the thumb stays up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr Early Access First Impressions: A very faithful port of the physical game with a somewhat unintuitive UI that does little to explain itself to the player. Worth buying if you're a fan of the game or have been interested in it.

---

(Note that this is from the perspective of someone who owns and enjoys the physical game. The review is a combination of the actual game and its port.)

For the card game itself...

Do you like casual card games? Do you like sprite art? Do you often get nostalgic over the 8-bit and 16-bit platformer days? You'll probably like Boss Monster. It's a fairly simple game where you play as - well, a boss monster in a video game. Your goal is to build a dungeon that can both attract and kill any heroes dumb enough to step foot in it while competing against other boss monsters attempting to do the same.

Besides building your dungeon, you also have access to spells that can change the outcome of the game dramatically if used properly by buffing heroes in another boss' dungeon, disabling their rooms so they can't affect the hero and so on. Every room has an affect of its own that can sometimes interact with other rooms within your dungeon, offering a decent amount of strategic options for placement without really racking the brain too much.

Overall, it's an extremely fun casual game to play with friends and relax with. It makes a great 'opening' or 'closing' game to a board/card game night and it's highly recommended from me.

As for the port...

It's adequate. It has a large amount of visual polish and the tutorial is sufficient in teaching a new player how to play. The UI is a bit unintuitive, however, as it does very little to offer feedback to the player. The tutorial does nothing to explain the UI either and makes it a bit worse and leaves the player to sort of poke around until they figure it out for themselves... which may involve a destroyed room or discarded card on accident. The UI was pretty clearly made with touch screens in mind first and PC players a distant second. The little summaries of all of the bosses are quite nice and help keep track of the game state very well.

That all said, though, it isn't exactly a puzzle. Most of the functionality is fairly obvious. Want to use a card's effect? Click it. It does lack solid visual feedback for selecting cards - especially at the beginning of a game where you need to discard two cards from your hand. In the case of a dungeon with a lot of traps, activating the effect of one trap room immediately sends you back to the card selection screen without any positive indicator that you've actually activated it until you click OK. More feedback as to what the player's selections and actions are would be nice.

Another thing is the Halt button. It's unnecessary and misleading. Clicking it actually doesn't immediately halt the game - it just presents options, including probably the most important one of all: Pass All. This skips all of your actions for the current dungeon being adventured through. If you have no spell cards in hand and it's currently your opponent's adventuring turn, for example, there is no reason for you to stop the game. If more people knew about this, the games would go SIGNIFICANTLY faster. Rather than have the Halt button, just make the three options (Play A Card, Pass Once, Pass All) visible throughout the entirety of the adventuring phase.

Overall, these are mostly minor issues that don't detract from the experience overly much. Since the game is still in early access, I expect the developer to make a few passes over the UI before its 'actual' release. What's here now, though, is perfectly playable and still enjoyable. It's still Boss Monster. It is not integrated into Steamworks and goes purely through their own servers (likely to prepare for crossplatform play similar to Ascension,) but online play has so far been smooth for me. I haven't tested inviting friends to private games yet nor have I tried the hotseat play option so take this review for what it is: a first impressions review.

With already owning the card based version and tablet edition for when im out and about, all I can say about boss monster is that it is perfect for beginners and established card game players alike. It is not a complex card game at base level but add in the strategy and thought process to each player competing and it can get as complex as you'd like.

What I like about the PC version is the support for online games, being able to play anyone is amazing. The layout is really decent for the type of game it is, not cluttering when adding more A.I players. The auto attack equation helps, especially if someone new to the game can't outright figure out if they can take on any heroes. The unlocks once they are out will make this game even better than it is. The quality of the images for the cards and the overall colour and detail is really good, and makes the game much more impressive.

There are only a few niggles with the game that I would like to address though. One is the pass and play feature. Although this allows 'couch multiplayer' of sorts, for me personally, would prefer to sit at a table and play this game with physical cards, which only leaves the single player A.I and the online capabilities. Another worry is the sounds. I know they are there for fun and interaction with the cards but they can get a little irritating as they are played after every attack in a room. If they only made the noise once (maybe when they are built) I would be fine with it, but ergo I have had to turn off the sound in the settings. One tiny idea from me would also be to put a total attack number somewhere in your play area, not for me as a player personally who plays the physical game and has to, but for new players who don't want to be adding up their attack total each time.

Overall though, its a perfect game for card beginners to learn what Boss Monster is about and have fun with it with friends, so I highly recommend it for those looking for something new, but if you have the physical edition, its only qualities are what I've said before, the A.I and online. For pass n play multiplayer, I will probably stick with the cards, but when I have no one to play with, the PC edition is where I'm going to go for my Boss Monster urges.

Plus at a price of £5, theres no argument if you dont have the physical game, as this is cheaper than the physical edition, and will allow you to enjoy it as much as me.

I saw this game out in EA after I first tried tabletop version 5 months ago and patiently waited for it to leave the workshop before buying it. Last week, it came out and I bought the game and all DLCs on sale for the price of a Subway meal. My fears of massive bugginess from what other reviews stated were for nought; I run a Windows 7 Dell Laptop and, after many games (2, 3 and 4 player) I have yet to experience ANY major bugs. I haven't tried Multiplayer partly due to that no one is on it, but hopefully that will change in time. Human opponents would be way more fun than AI. What I'd like to see in it: more unlockable features through winning X number of games; a full rulebook (outside of the Tutorial); more card options (likely in future); more warm bodies in Multiplayer mode!
What I do see in it: smooth, bug-free gameplay; tounge-in-cheek humor; well-crafted soundtrack; a faithful and user-friendly adaptation of the tabletop version

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Browsing the many booths at Anime Central in Chicago, one card game caught my friend's eye. It stood out from all the other card games because it featured pixel art, and the box was reminiscent of a NES game box. So we picked it up and took it home with us. We had such a blast playing it and sharing it with other friends. That card game was Boss Monster.

Imagine my excitement when I found out a digital version was coming to Steam, with online multiplayer.

The digital version isn't  perfect, but for an early access title it's pretty solid. It's rather easy to pick up if you're familiar with the card game. If you haven't played then you might be turned away by the sudden wall of text you have to read which is the tutorial, but once you get it down and play a few rounds it begins to make sense.

There are many options and possibilities for different kinds of dungeons. Some will work well with your boss character, some will not. It's also possible to get a really unlucky hand and just be stuck at the bottom the entire game, but it rarely happens. You win some and you lose some.

A couple things I would personally like to see is a better tutorial which teaches through experience rather then having to memorize text, and an option to turn off the timer in multiplayer as it gets a little annoying sometimes, especially if you're fairly new to the game.

Overall it's a fun game that deserves to be played. Buy it, play it, love it.

First things first, I love Boss Monster. It is an amazing game. I helped kick start it and I helped kickstart this port. My negative recomendation is not for the Boss Monster game but for this Steam port.

Anyways, now on to the review of the port. I will try to cover everything that was my initial impression:

This port feels very rushed and poorly done.

The Good:
-Music is nice.
-Card art is pretty as ever.
- The digital exclusive cards are great.

The Bad:

- The UI is extremely unituitive. I managed to destroy one of my rooms without even realizing it (which was hilarious.) It's hard to tell where to go to play certain things and what is going on/what phase you are in.

-  Play moves at glacial speed. One of the fun things about Boss Monster is the speed at which you can knock out a game with a group of buds. With this port it takes unbelievably long to play a match. I understand why the need for the 'halt' window is needed but a vote to skip function would be great. (So when playing with one friend you guys can just mash that button when not waiting to play a card).

- The control scheme feels like a direct rip of a mobile port. When selecting some things the only way to do so is click and drag the list of options, which while intuitive on a phone feels very clumsy on a computer. Srolling doesn't work.

To sum it up: Boss Monster is as good as ever and I love it for what it is. However, the port is poorly done and needs work. I couldn't even sit through one game with my friend because of the glacial play. It just takes so damn long to do anything.

I will update this review if they make updates to the UI or can speed up play.

So, I love the tabletop version of this game.
The digital.. does not shine yet the way one would like. The PC version is a shoddy port of the mobile version that has clunky controls that require a dozen clicks for everything, and everything is all 'click and drag through'- i'm sure it's OK on a touch screen but FFS this is the PC port, better mouse support!

Then comes the port of paper to digital. Let's be honest here: Boss Monster is not a game you ('most gamers') will sit down specifically to play. It's what we call a filler game. Waiting for Pizza, 'couple players in the D&D group are late.. any time there's a bit of time to fill, you can break it out and have a few minutes of silly fun.

There is precisely ONE benefit of the digital edition over the physical edition: the price. Outside of that, there's NO reason to go digital.
There's not a lot of synergy and strategy to the game, so the digital doesn't help you 'practice'.
There's not a lot of convoluted maths that the digital edition streamlines.
The mechanics are not particularly engaging, nor are they complicated.
There isn't a real 'story' to the game.
There's not much in the way of fun graphics.

In other words, this is a PC port of a mobile port of a tabletop card game, and it plays just like a tabletop filler card game, without any real advantage over the tabletop edition.

Also, the only expansion so far that's out, requires you to win the game /40/ times to get? Blood hell. I'm not sure I've actually played the tabletop edition 40 times yet, and definitely haven't won it 40 times.

It occurs to me that this game is still in early access, and the developers might read reviews looking for things that need improvements, so I will add some things which could change my rating:

Improved UI with better mouse support.
A few less clicks to accomplish basic tasks. (The 'halt' button, for example is needless, there should be a countdown bar with 4 options: Play spell, use room, go, go-all.)
The ability to select the boss you play, or at least get dealt a new one.
Ability to increase the game speed.
Allowance of 'house rules' (increase/decrease hand size, alter starting card distribution, alter souls/wounds required to win/lose, etc.)

First of all, it's a bad pc version of a mobile game, the control are not intuitive, and even after playing a bit i still mess up the few basic action (like hitting esc to go back when all it does is open the menu), or i just guess to use my arrow keys to switch between cards !!!

The tutorial doesnt explain everything, i didnt even know i had to play against someone, how the treasure system worked to attract heroes to YOUR dungeon and not the opponent (if you can read between the line and tested the game before hand it make sense, but when you never played it once or heard about its gameplay ... well, its confusing). I had other pleople with no experience with the game and they made the same mistake. It's something relatively basic to make your game tested by different people without explaining them what to do or how to do it (expect with the information the game provides you) so you dont make that kind of mistakes.

With the functionnality and polish the game provides it wouldnt in no way bought that game : No deck management, no control on where you set your rooms, graphics could have been a lot better even for a 2D card game, like i said controls are awfull.

I played a bit multiplayer with a friend and we it was just okay.


So i dont recommend it to you unless you are a real fan and what to play it with someone else on pc who doesnt have the mobile version. I hope they patch at least the control problems to make it more fluid and intuitive, also to speed the game which are long in my opinion.
I would say it's just a really poor mobile port to make more money ... dont make them think it's a good thing to do.

reviewText:
Intro: Boss Monster is a game that rekindled my interest in both card and board games. The video game however, is a big, cheap, disappointment.

Full Video Review With Insight On How The Game Actually Plays:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ru4L0nb1m7s

Below is entirely focused on the port:

Gameplay:
Boss Monster PC is ported from Ipad and it shows. Menus aren't designed for a mouse and keyboard, windowed mode barely works with their being a pseudo borderless that alt-tabs the game without minimizing but requires you alt-tab to get back in which makes it frustrating when you are on a timer. Windowed mode shrinks into a tiny box that you can't make bigger because the game features no resolution options. Controls are at times incredibly sloppy. Some buttons are incredibly close to the corner of the screen which will cause you to alt-tab" out of the game at times when you click off-screen. Multiplayer is a joke with no one playing and even if you find one person you are given a timed window to get other players
hoursPlayed: every random game you play online will be 1v1. On the technical side
voteText: Bad AI and bugs aren't common but they do happen. Sometimes cards won't work and AI will do stupid things. The porting issue rears its ugly head as it screws with your controls. It can be very easy to make a mistake and you have very few moments in the game where you can correct those mistakes. The game also sells DLC because of course it does. Now I would be fine with this but with the multiplayer as dead as it is
helpfulPercent: it just hurts the game even more because you will be using these expansions against AI. Now the biggest nut-kicker is that Tools of a Hero-Kind is a pay-for expansion just like in the original card game. The original game had some early-on balancing issues where one player could be completely screwed by hero output and bad RNG. Tools of Hero-Kind helped fix it
votesHelpful:
they didn't decide to add this or any of the other DLC to make it feel like a complete experience.

Visuals:
Boy oh boy does this hurt me the most. Animations are incredibly static. While the cards are animated decently
votesTotal: almost everything else is lifeless. When heroes move between rooms in your dungeons it is just the same as how you move them between rooms in the actual card game. Heroes pop out of their cards only to slide across each room without move any body parts
votesFunny: boss have no idle animations at all. They just stand their in an incredibly disappointing manner. While there are actual backgrounds that are what you expect
commentsCount: there are no animations or anything interesting happening in them. Static
column18: environments. The only thing they got right is the UI
column19: it's incredibly-well layed out with a decent tutorial to back it up. Except they manage to screw that up and not include a counter or a deck or any indication of how many heroes are left in each deck. I thought the whole point of a video game adaption was to bring a card game to life. It certainly isn't going used for playing with others online because as I mentioned before
column20:
online is dead.

Sound:
Sound is the closest thing I can consider good about the game but they still don't cross mediocre. There is one music track in this game
column21:
it's good but there's just one. Why not have some dynamic music where when it's your turn but you are low on health but about to win the game with no spell cards to protect you from a player attack that could absolutely wreck you. Where's that tension I would get when playing with friends? That music would have at least accounted for the slow pacing in the adventure phase. Otherwise audio is decent with sound effects being nice to the ears but they do re-use a lot of them.
